contentrichtext.text: {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2013}} '''Giuseppe Antonio Giachimo Cerutti''' (June 13, 1738 – February 3, 1792) was a French-Italian author and politician. [[File:Joseph-Antoine Cerutti.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Cerutti published his works in France using the name Joseph-Antoine Cerutti.]] Cerutti was born in [[Turin]]. Having joined the [[Society of Jesus]], he became professor at the [[Jesuit]] college at [[Lyon]]. In 1762, in reply to the attacks on his order, he published an ''Apologie générale de l'institut et de la doctrine des Jésuites'', which won him much fame and some exalted patronage; notably that of the ex-king [[Stanisław Leszczyński|Stanislaus of Poland]] and of his grandson the [[Dauphin of France|Dauphin]]. During the agitations that preceded the [[French Revolution]] Cerutti took the popular side, and in 1788 published a pamphlet, ''Mémoire pour le peuple français'', in which in a clear and trenchant style he advocated the claims of the ''tiers état'' ([[Estates General (France)|third estate]]). In May 1789 he presided over the electors of Paris, by whom in January 1791 he was chosen member of the administration of the department and afterwards deputy to the [[Legislative Assembly (France)|Legislative Assembly]]. He was a friend of [[Honoré Mirabeau]], whose policy he supported and whose funeral oration he gave. ==''La Feuille villageoise''== Probably the largest of Cerutti's literary enterprises was the newspaper ''La Feuille villageoise'' founded by him, on September 30, 1790, in collaboration with [[Jean-Paul Rabaut Saint-Etienne]] and [[Philippe Antoine Grouvelle]]. ''La Feuille villageoise'' was a highly successful newspaper during the French Revolution. It is unusual among revolutionary journals for having been targeted not at Paris or another large city, but to rural audiences. The paper was extremely influential in much of the French countryside and had approximately 15,000 subscribers in 1791.{{sfn|Edelstein|1971|p=68}} Actual news reporting played only a minor part in the newspaper's writings: political commentary was by far the primary content. ''La Feuille villageoise'' was thoroughly partisan in its republican favoritism, and unambiguous in its didactic presentation of its opinions.{{sfn|Darnton|1989|p=159}}. Less vitriolic and more analytical than many of its more infamous contemporary newspapers, ''La Feuille villageoise'' also distinguished itself by rarely identifying individual politicians as enemies of its ideas, but instead relied on a simple trope of ''aristocrates'' and ''patriotes''.{{sfn|Darnton|1989|p=158}} ==Citations== {{Reflist}} ==References== {{Refbegin}} * {{vcite journal | author= Edelstein, Melvin | author.= | title=La Feuille villageoise, the Revolutionary Press, and the Question of Rural Political Participation | title.=| articletype= | journal=French Historical Studies | journal.= | edition= | journalformat= | date=1971 | update= | volume=7 | issue=2 | pages=175–203 | jstor=285982 | oclc=480980117 | archiveurl= | archivedate=| ref=CITEREFEdelstein1971 }} * {{vcite book | author=Darnton, Robert; Roche, Daniel | title=Revolution in Print: The Press in France 1775–1800 | publisher=University of California Press | isbn=0-520-06431-3 | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_aVPJtVWbyQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Revolution+in+Print:+The+Press+in+France+1775%E2%80%931800#v=onepage&q&f=false | ref=CITEREFDarnton1989 }} *{{1911}} {{Refend}} ==External links== * {{IMSLP|id=Cérutti, Joseph-Antoine-Joachim}} {{Authority control|VIAF=71400552}} <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]] --> {{Persondata |NAME = Cérutti, Giuseppe |ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Cérutti, Joseph-Antoine-Joachim |SHORT DESCRIPTION = French-Italian author and politician |DATE OF BIRTH = June 13, 1738 |PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Turin]] |DATE OF DEATH = February 3, 1792 |PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cerutti, Giuseppe}} [[Category:1738 births]] [[Category:1792 deaths]] [[Category:Italian Jesuits]] [[Category:Italian emigrants to France]] [[Category:People from Turin]] [[Category:French people of Italian descent]] [[Category:French newspaper founders]]
